questions.text: A system that manages electronic signatures for release approvals would be classified as:

options.explanation: Electronic signatures directly impact regulatory compliance, making this high risk.
Electronic signatures have direct impact on compliance, requiring full validation.
Per Section 5.2, systems with direct impact on product quality, safety, or regulatory compliance (e.g., electronic signatures) are classified as high risk.
All computer systems used in the QMS must be classified.

questions.text: How often must validated systems undergo periodic review?

options.explanation: The review cycle is annual, not semi-annual.
Per Section 5.7, validated systems are reviewed annually.
Two years exceeds the required review frequency.

options.text: Only when a problem is reported
options.explanation: Reviews are scheduled annually, not only triggered by problems.

questions.text: A security patch to a validated system always requires full revalidation.
questions.explanation: Per Section 5.6, minor updates including patches are assessed for impact. Revalidation is only performed if validated functions are affected.

questions.text: Which validation qualification is only required for high-risk systems?

options.explanation: OQ is required for both high and medium risk systems.
Per Section 5.4, IQ is only required for high-risk systems. Medium risk systems require OQ only.
Intended use documentation is required for all risk levels.
Risk classification is required for all systems, not just high risk.

questions.text: Which of the following would trigger revalidation of a system?

options.explanation: Adding users is routine administration, not a revalidation trigger.

options.text: Major version upgrade of the system
options.explanation: Per Section 5.6, major version upgrades are a revalidation trigger.
Cosmetic changes do not affect validated functions.
Contract renewals do not change system functionality.
